ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to take field notes and be more aware of cultural nuances.

I learned a lot in this course, more than I can explain. Anthropology, at first, was difficult for me: I could not understand the logic and the science behind it. I think this course taught me how to observe better, listen better, and try to gather more information before jumping to conclusions and judging.
Conducting field research within the methodology of ethnography; reading exemplary ethnographies; discussing the ethics of ethnography
I learnt about how to conduct anthropological fieldwork and research.

I learnt about the ethics, logistics and art of doing ethnographic research. The most formative lessons came from performing ethnographic research and from working one on one with Prof. Lynch to plan my research and improve my writing. I have a much clearer understanding of the rigours of performing ethnographic fieldwork and of transforming observations into analytical writing.
I learned about ethnographic writing And the anthropological approach to knowledge production.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Freedom to choose topics that interest you. More feedback on field notes would be good.

I think the great strength of the course is the Professor's positivity and willingness to help and understand the material better.

The significant weakness of the course is understanding the material. It often seems that things are too vague: for example, how to organize an ANTH paper.

Strengths: well-organized, discussion-based, Professor Lynch is wonderful!

Weaknesses: we could read more ethnographies...
I enjoyed the attention that was given to the methodology of fieldwork. I feel like coursework could have been less reduced (less fieldwork journals).

Majority of the courses strength came from the practical exercises and from Prof. Lynchs instruction. I suspect that either because it was a 9am seminar in Watson or because people came from such a wide range of disciplines and with differing goals. The kind of engaging seminar discussions that youd expect between students were largely absent except for a few instances when we were discussing more polarising topics or when people posed questions to each other directly which felt like a loss.

The class covered a host of important issues that ethnographers must keep in mind when conducting research. We explored the entire research process, from how to craft a compelling research question, to how to design an ethnographic study, to issues like positionality, voice, ethics. A weakness was that the class discussion sometimes fell short because there were a few students who were taking this class as their primary introduction to anthropology, and I would have liked it if we were able to push our thinking beyond an introductory level

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It provides a lot of context and builds skills for writing ethnographies.
I will recommend this course to another student
Yes! Even if you're not an anthropology major, this course will teach you how to incorporate anthropological thought into any qualitative research project at hand.
Yes, for anthropology majors or prospective anthropology students! However, I can imagine that for students who are new to anthropology, the learning curve for this course might be a bit steep.
I would but I think that the course could use restructuring
this class is a great methods course for students interested in doing their own anthropological research.
